title-group.article-title: Why Social Security Expenditure in the 1980s has Risen Faster than Expected: the Role of Unemployment

p.mixed-citation: For 1981-82, the relevant PEWP (Cmnd 8175) provides a cash equivalent of aggregate social security expenditure in 1980 survey prices, and this can be used to gross up expenditure components. For 1980-81 (Cmnd 7841), however, no such figure is given. Furthermore forecasts of planning totals for 2 or 3 years ahead in survey prices must be converted to cash prices. The technique adopted was to use a mixture of the information on ex-post forecasting errors stated in subsequent PEWPs together with inflation forecasts, to estimate cash-total equivalents for these earlier years.

The growth of unemployment here means the increase in percentage points. Thus the regions with high unemployment growth were Northern Ireland, the North, West Midlands and the North West. These with the lowest growth of unemployment were East Anglia, South East, Greater London and the South West. It should be noted that this definition of areas of high unemployment growth will tend to coincide quite closely with areas with high absolute levels of unemployment.

Two other groups with potentially complex labour supply responses to rising unemployment are school leavers and the wives of unemployed men. The behaviour of these groups in response to rising unemployment is discussed in some detail in Micklewright et al. (1988) and Kell and Wright (1988) respectively.

Lone parents were ascribed the same 'applicable amount' for Housing Benefit as married couples, and, unlike unemployed people, were entitled to the (higher) long term rate of Supplementary Benefit after one year on benefit.
